title: True South, Season 8 Starts With Exploring The Notion Of Going Home
description: The premiere episode of the latest season of Emmy award-winning “True South” takes viewers on a deeply personal journey to Clinton, Ga., where host John T. Edge was born.
content:
The premiere episode of the latest season of Emmy award-winning “ takes viewers on a deeply personal journey to Clinton, Ga., where host John T. Edge was born. It’s a poignant tale exploring the power of home, family and making connections through food. Here’s the backstory of how it went down.

Looking forward to looking back

The mission of this evocative series is to take viewers to places they’ve likely never been before and to shine a light on the American South, demonstrating the rich textures of that vast region. Its irresistible hook is always the food, prepared with love and care, often at humble family-run operations that have been in business for generations.

Edge, author of the best-selling and one of the founders of the Southern Foodways Alliance, makes a savvy guide. He introduces viewers to the people who share their stories, offering bite-sized glimpses into what makes this part of the world special.

During the opening episode of Season 8, which debuts Sept. 2 on the SEC Network, the tables are turned and it’s the host who shares.

“I felt it was important to show people a little bit more of myself, to explain why I do what I do and care so much about the place we call home,” Edge explained in a recent phone interview.

The seed was first planted in Season 3, in the episode that focused on the value of family recipes.

“We often talk about restaurants as second homes and it occurred to me I hadn’t really talked about why I left my first home,” he said. “I decided to call my own bluff.”

Without spilling tea and revealing spoilers, let’s just say Edge had a bumpy ride while growing up. He and his father would often “run away”, heading down the road to eat chopped pork sandwiches at or savor the best chili dogs at . Those beloved landmarks are showcased in this episode, but not in the typical food porn fashion.

Once again, the point is gently driven home that shared meals and good conversation are an essential part of the human experience.

That’s true whether you’re meeting up with a genial stranger or a room full of folks who you haven’t seen in 40-plus years. The latter was a reunion of sorts, with friends and former neighbors in the tiny town of Clinton.

Edge said: “I’m not trying to explain away the chasm that divides many of us, but I do want to focus attention on the possibilities. I feel immense gratitude that I get to go home again and reconcile with my place. I think many of us want to do that, that’s a very human drive. To find a way to love the people and place that loved you, to make peace, accept and love the place. At that gathering with old friends, some who I had played Little League with, I hadn’t seen some of them in 45 years when I left to go to college. Not everyone is afforded the opportunity to go back home, but I was."

He said he was so happy he got the chance to thank the people of Jones County for showing up for him: "I instantly felt comfortable with them and with myself.”

The fitting bookends of this episode includes servings of glimpses into Edge’s chosen hometown of Oxford, Miss., where he and his wife, Blair Hobbs, make the rounds, stopping at Square Books and Chicory Market. That beautifully shot footage – which features charming cameo appearances from Lurleen, the family’s dog – are accompanied by original music composed by Mark Yacovone, a multi-instrumentalist from Oxford, who composed three of the songs for this episode and led the band that performed them.

The stirring soundtrack is another reason to check out this series, which is produced by . Yes, of course, there’s a .

Before tuning in, it’s important to note that watching True South is likely to cause hunger pangs. The deep dive into some of the cooks and managers at various locations only adds to those mouthwatering moments.

Just try watching the team at Fresh Air chop pork shoulders and hams that have been cooked low-and-slow, making sandwich plates heavy with that meat alongside sides of sweet slaw and Brunswick stew and if you’re a fan of that kind of fare, you might be tempted to look up flights to the nearest airport.

And at the 109-year-old Nu-Way, loyal patrons might strike up a conversation about their preferred order before talk takes an interesting turn. That’s exactly what happened during filming last May when Edge ended up sharing a meal and talking story with fellow fan, Johnny Hollingshed, Jr. “Places like Nu-Way and Fresh Air, places that feel like a second home, showcase the possibilities of the best kind of American experience,” he said.

Finally, these tasty trips Edge and the True South crew have taken over the past few years inspired the author to pick up the pen again. His latest book, “House of Smoke” hits the shelves Sept. 16.

Its official description reads a bit like the tone set by episode one in Season 8 of True South:

“The author of The Potlikker Papers: A Food History of the Modern South tells his own story this time. Of growing up in a house wrecked by violence and a South haunted by racism. And of how his search for home led him to find escape and belonging through food. Until he realizes that gathering at the table is just one small step toward reckoning.”

Edge says it’s easy to draw that connection, but points out the episode wasn’t driven by the book: “It was really doing the show all these years that drove me to write the book.” Sounds fitting. Could there be a “True South” cookbook down the road? Hope so.
summary: The premiere episode of the Emmy-winning series "True South" begins with a personal journey to the birthplace of host John T. Edge in Clinton, Ga., where he was born. The series explores the power of home, family, and connections through food. The show's mission is to take viewers to places they've never been before and to showcase the rich textures of the American South. The host, Edge, introduces viewers to the people who share their stories and provides a detailed account of his journey. The opening episode of Season 8, which debuts on the SEC Network on Sept. 2, includes brief glimpses into Edge's hometown of Oxford, Miss., and original music composed by Mark Yacovone.
shortSummary: The premiere of season 8 of "True South” explores the personal journey of John T. Edge's childhood in Clinton, Ga., and connects viewers to the rich, Southern food culture.

One of the hottest home run hitters in baseball partnered with a beloved Pacific Northwest craft beer producer to come up with a brew proudly bearing his nickname. Here’s why you need to raise a glass and toast the Big Dumper beer.
How it started
Cal Raleigh is having quite a season, making history as the first MLB catcher to crush the home run derby at the All Star game. This month, he broke long-standing records for the number of homers scored by a catcher in a season, banging out No. 50 on Aug. 25 against the San Diego Padres.
Naturally, this kind of superstar performance has led to some cool endorsement deals, but there’s one collaboration that began early in the season.
“His management team approached us about doing a collaboration,” said Phil Bannan, who runs Scuttlebutt Brewing Co., the company his parents established in 1995 in Everett, Wash., 30 minutes north of Seattle. “At first, we couldn’t believe it was real. But, of course, we were so excited. We couldn’t sleep at night if we hadn’t gone for it.”
Turns out that Cal played for the Everett Aquasox when he was in the minor leagues, and his host family brought him to the Scuttlebutt Brewing tap house.
A few months ago, Raleigh spent some time hanging at the brewery, getting the lowdown on various styles from the head brewer, Adam Chittick. “They talked about different grains we use and smelled different types of hops,” Bannan said.
Cal leaned in one the lighter lager styles in tasting through various test batch samples and, boom! The Big Dumper beer was created. “It’s a lager, but one that’s got some complexity,” Bannan said.
How it’s going
After launching on Aug. 15, the beer has been a huge hit, selling out quickly when it manages to making it to the shelf. “Our distributors have been asking for more,” Bannan said. “It’s coming.”
In the meantime, it’s been nothing short of thrilling for the folks who started the family-run business nearly three decades ago. Mom and Dad and the grandson got to meet Cal on the field at T-Mobile Park and pose for a photo. “He’s just such a nice guy,” Bannan said.
And speaking of the ballpark, if/when the Big Dumper beer ever finds its way onto the taps, it’s absolutely essential it be paired with the Big Dumper dumplings.
If you’re looking for the quintessential food partner at Scuttlebutt’s waterfront restaurant, there’s many options, but nothing’s finer than a Big Dumper beer and an order of hand-dipped and battered Alaska cod fish and chips.

Author
John T. Edge
John T. Edge writes and hosts the Emmy Award-winning television show TrueSouth on the SEC Network, ESPN, Disney, and Hulu. Edge also writes a restaurant column for Garden & Gun. His 2017 book The Potlikker Papers: A Food History of the Modern South was named one of the best books of the year by NPR and Publishers Weekly. Edge serves the University of Mississippi as a teacher, writer-in-residence, and director of the Mississippi Lab. And he serves the University of Georgia as a mentor in their low-residency MFA program in narrative nonfiction. He lives in Oxford, Mississippi, with his wife, the artist Blair Hobbs.
Learn More about John T. Edge

The Potlikker Papers
“Edge's book means to be about food, but quickly veers into a close examination of the Deep South, before revealing itself as the smartest history of race in America in a generation." Jack Hitt, author, Bunch of Amateurs
“To read Potlikker is to understand modern Southern history at a deeper level than you're used to. Not just a history of Southern food; it also stands as a singularly important history of the South itself." The Bitter Southerner
Beginning with the pivotal role of cooks in the civil rights movement, John T. Edge narrates the region’s journey from a hive of racism to a hotbed of American immigration, tracing how the food of working class Southerners has become a signature of American cuisine.
Restaurants were battlegrounds during the civil rights movement. Access to food and ownership of traditions were key contentions on the long and fitful march toward racial equality. The Potlikker Papers begins in 1955 as black cooks and maids fuelled the Montgomery bus boycott and it concludes in 2015 as a newer South came into focus, enriched by the arrival of immigrants from Mexico, Vietnam, and many points in between.
Along the way, The Potlikker Papers tracks the evolution of Southern identity, from the back-to-the-land movement of the 1970s that began in the Tennessee hills to the rise of fast and convenience foods modeled on Southern staples. Edge narrates the gentrification that gained traction in North Carolina and Louisiana restaurants of the 1980s and the artisanal renaissance that reconnected farmers and cooks in the 1990s and 2000s.
Wrenching changes transformed the South over the last two generations. During that same span, Southerners transformed America. The Potlikker Papers interprets these shifts in beliefs and identities, revealing how Southern food has become a shared culinary language for the nation.

The episode blends stories of Southern food culture with themes of home, belonging, and reconciliation, underscoring the power of shared meals.
